text:
All though I would still ventilate the workroom while working with any resin. I think the saving grace here is that it's printing and curing small thin layer at a time so you not getting as larger amount VoC floating in the air like mixing resins or an open vat like a resin printer.

Though this was an interesting machine that's taken the resin printing of larger machine and gives a smaller and easier to maintain printing profile for the resin to the process.

text:
I was looking this up because I was curious to buy and thank you for this video. I'm certainly going to pass.

Mainly because it's crystal clear now that they're going to absolutely drain you of money due to the ink. Every 3 hours to cycle a bit from their already small cartridges (I understand the importance of this in a uv printer which leads me to:) + no area for you to do a manual access cleaner flush yourself that I'm seeing to prevent that if you choose to unplug your machine yourself and instead do it via a cartridge you have to shell out money for + ¬£300 (?!) to buy a set that is only from them  = you spending way more than you've spent on the machine itself in a relatively short amount of time. It's set up to money sink you from the start.

Not to mention ink that isn't even guaranteed to be sold for as long as you have this machine because they might discontinue.

text: I put down my deposit so now I'm just waiting for the Kick to start.  I have a few questions, I'm hoping you can answer.  1) How long do the resin cartridges last, ie: how much can you print?  I know that is somewhat subjective, based on what you print, and how much of each color you use, but take your Mando print on wood.  How much resin did that take?  How many of those could you print with a single kit?  2) Since the printer has to lay down a white layer under anything that isn't being printed on a white surface, is the white tank bigger than the colors?  I think I saw somewhere that the ink kit would be around $300 to replace, and if you're going through that (and/or a cleaning kit) every few months, that has a pretty high cost of usage.  3) I saw another video about printing on tumblers and cups and it seemed to suggest that the machine was pretty picky about the sizes and shapes of tumblers it works with.  The ones you demo'd appear to be Eufy branded, so not just any old tumbler.  It loses a lot of flexibility if you can only print on their materials.  4) The sticker lamination set up looks like it might require some kind of transfer material, and I'm wondering if that is also proprietary.  I live in Alaska, so I'm really cautious about new tech with proprietary media / materials, because all too often companies don't ship to Alaska or treat it like a completely foreign country.  ($200 to ship a $99 thing - Xtool won't even ship replacement lenses or mirrors to Alaska).  Thanks in advance.
video: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV

text:
I have 2 concerns. A craftsman should own his tools or he will never get anywhere in life. $20 bucks a month to rent software is crazy!

My 2nd concern is the whole idea of vaporizing metal as opposed to machining away metal.

A small home cnc mill could use the same image to cut the metal away. The metal shavings could be melted down or sold as scrap.

Venting the vaporized metal fumes in or even outside the home still sounds like a bad idea in the long run.
video: 3D Engrave Any Image Onto a Coin (Step by Step Pro

text: To anyone who is looking at the recreative side of laser engraving and cutting... I have the Xtool 20W. 1- their software is great and is enough for my use. I do not need to purchase and learn lightburn. 2- You will need air assist , an enclosure, a metal bee bed, an air purifier. That pushes up the price a lot. And knowing this, I wish I had gone for a desktop CO2 Machine with autofocus and a camera. The end price will have been about the same and instead of having a toy that really needs lots of upgrade, I would have the right machine...

text:
Wait, if it's taking an existing image and then just putting your product in it, as you showed in the example with the Emma tag on the folded napkin, how is that not plagiarism? It's not like it's even really making a new image, you're literally feeding it the image you're copying, call it inspiration all you like, but it's just plagiarism with the extra step of telling the computer to do it for you. And frankly, why bother with chatGPT if you're just gonna plagiarize things, you can already do that for free.

As for selling your photos with generated images of your product, I would say that's just false advertising. If you're portraying something as a photo of the product, and it's not a photo of the product, you're just lying, again, with extra steps. And sure, if you want to sell your product by lying, that's hardly a new idea - just ask El Nasir - but let's at least be honest with ourselves about what we're doing here.

Look, man, I'm not entirely against AI being used as a tool. There are even ethically trained AI models out there(even if ChatGPT isn't one of them). But this this isn't helping folks, it's the opposite. It's just a way to have people offload essential - and fairly easy to learn, in my experience - skills for a creative business to a tool they don't control, and ensuring they are turbo-screwed when those tools change or go away, as well as essentially telling people to do sketchy and in some given examples downright unethical things like it's normal and fine.

If you want an example, let's say, hey, someone spun up a business doing portraits of people in Ghibli style using chatGPT...they'd have some angry customers right about now, because in the time between filming and this video being made, ChatGPT has taken that feature offline, with no indication of when it will return. Which is especially ironic, considering Brandon's quite reasonable complaints with hardware about not having it in your control, and a third party being able to shut you down arbitrarily, at any time, with no recourse.

And no, I don't expect this comment to last too long, a few hours at most, whenever Brandon's part of the US wakes up. But that's fair enough, I've said my piece, so no skin off my nose.

Tengo 2 preguntas muy importantes. Qu√© longitud de manguera tienen las pistolas, es la misma longitud en la m√°quina de 800W y la de 1200W.
Y la pregunta m√°s importante qu√© tipo de conector o enchufe üîå tienen las m√°quinas en Europa, conector Shusko?? Es que he visto que la m√°quina de 800W necesita una potencia de 15A (hasta aqu√≠ no hay problema pues los enchufes de las casas europeas normalmente resisten 16A) el problema es con la m√°quina de 1200W que necesita 23A. As√≠ que definitivamente me gustar√≠a saber qu√© enchufe üîå trabe ambas m√°quinas, deber√≠an poner datos y fotos de esto que pregunto es su web

text:
since photonics x1 pro weld machine is around $2800 on KS then for this you are look at about $6000 because of the CNC aspect which is the only additional feature so let say if it on Ks $6000 to start and then maybe after launch price could range from $6000 to $12K at most. also not to mention Xtool is not know for any Business grade professional machine just prosumer, hobbyist and craftsman man. 

so they need to come in at an affordable price before they can have a foothold in a industrial class market segment. 

industrial class are not mainly concern about price as long as they have a way to generate a ROI on the machine investment. what tends to outweigh ROI is support and aftermarket sales. 

if Xtool wanted large scale business to buy into this they will need to have started approaching them for a long time as business of who would buy 1 - 2 or 5x would usually plan out the ROI, safety, aftermarket sales, e.t.c. 

I think they will be aiming the SUB 10K mark as most hobbyist will not put down 10K if the ROI is 5-10years you really want to have and ROI of 1year max as a small business. 2 year at max. 3-5 years if you are buying multiple. cause if you take long to get an ROI you loss foothold on market share fast has competition start start to get into the industry with similar machine and product and and your direct competitor start to gain market share.

so you all should be persuading Xtool for a KS and a price of around max 5K for early entry backers. 

12K is not a stretch for some people but within a year or 2 other company will make similar product do not forget xtool is a Chinese company so patent laws work differently there. am sure you will see similar very soon. it a first but not the last. and other companies will come with integrated or modular system easily.
